description.narrative: Public and civil society duty bearers with strengthened capacity are reducing disaster risks, as well as planning, preparing, and effectively responding to disasters, in accordance with UNICEF Core Commitments to Children in Humanitarian Action ., which contributes to Community-Based Management Of Acute Malnutrition, Infant And Young Child Feeding, Micronutrients, Nutrition And Emergencies, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2017, the most disadvantaged children and women are accessing an integrated package of high impact, good quality health and nutrition services.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Public and civil society duty bearers with strengthened capacity are reducing disaster risks, as well as planning, preparing, and effectively responding to disasters, in accordance with UNICEF Core Commitments to Children in Humanitarian Action .

description.narrative: UNICEF along with other cluster partners was able to treated 22,366 children (Boys: 9,462, Girls: 12,904) under 5 years of age for SAM with a cure rate of 89% (above sphere standards), resulted in a decrease of malnutrition related morbidity and mortality. | Status:Met | As-of Date:27/12/2017

title.narrative: 60% of the emergency affected populations are covered by an effective emergency response
Number of primary caregivers of children aged 0-23 months who received counselling on IYCF

actual.value:
2017:153,693 primary caregivers of children aged 0-23 months received counselling on IYCF, which may lead to positive behaviour change in breastfeeding and complementary feeding practices.
Timely trainings of Health Care Providers on IYCF and CMAM built their capacity to reach mother and caregivers thro
